loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Upgrading his banana plantation with manure and pesticides.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a water project business, distributing fresh water from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition she also owns real estate houses which contribute to her income. Fatuma faces a major challenge of competition from other water distributors in her area of operation. She hopes to open a retail shop business in the future.

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase building materials to renovate her real estate houses. She decided to join Yehu because of affordable financial services to small scale entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to renovate her real estate houses.

loans.name: Charlito

texts.en:
Charlito C. is from the village of Mandulog, Iligan City. He is 28 years old. Charlito is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a service-based business, providing motorela or habal-habal services (motorcycle transport) to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Charlito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of his motorcycle

location.town: Mandulog, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Zeina

texts.ar: زينه في عمر 34 سنة متزوجة وعلى عاتقها اربع اولاد تعمل في محل لبيع ادوات التنظيف لها في عمله 10 سنوات تحب عملها وتجيده تريد تأمين حياة سعيدة وكريمة لها ولعائلتها دائمة التطور وتحب التقدم في العمل وفي الحياة تريد من خلال طلب قرض لها من المجموعة الى شراء مواد جديدة للمحل وتطوير المصلحة وزيادة المدخول لأنها تتميز في محيطها بالدقة في العمل والتطور الدائم
texts.en: Zeina is 34, married and has the responsibility of supporting 4 children. She works in a shop selling household goods. She has been doing this for 10 years and loves her work very much. She wants to secure a comfortable life for herself and her children. She likes progress and advancement both in her work and in life in generA.. Through her loan she wants to purchase new stock for her shop and increase her profit and income. She is recognised by those around her for her attention to detail and her constant development.

loans.use: The purchase of goods for the shop, including vacuum cleaners and other raw materials

loans.name: Mark Odhiambo

texts.en:
Mark Odhiambo O. runs a bookshop in Umoja estate which is well populated and has many customers who comes to his shop. Mark is married and a father of two school going children.

He has applied for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced to KADET by a friend who is already a registered client. He intends to use the entire loan amount to buy more stock of text books, exercise books, and envelopes for sale.

With the additional income he will plow it back into the business by adding more stock. He hopes to grow his business and open another branch and give his children a good education. He is a humble and hardworking man

loans.use: To add more stock of text books, exercise books, and envelopes

loans.name: Servando

texts.en:
Servando does farming for a living. He owns land in the town of Banga that he cultivates, planting and harvesting rice crops. He has been engaged in farming for nineteen years now. He does his best to increase his harvest and earnings.

Servando needs fertilizers and other farm supplies. He asked for a loan of 10,000 PHP which he will use to fund his farm. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Isu Lomama Group

texts.en:
Beyisile is 54 years old and married with two children, ages 11 and 32. She runs a small business in Stanger, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. In the photo above, she is wearing a white scarf around her head.

She's been in this business for five years and sells handcrafts and potatoes from her home and elsewhere. She also takes care of other two relatives. She says that the main challenge to her business is that the customers do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Business and KIVA to buy handcraft materials and potatoes. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her family life and her business. In five years time she would like to build a shelter for her business.

loans.use: Buy handcraft materials and potatoes

loans.name: Callixte

texts.fr:
Callixte K., est un homme de 54 ans, né à Bujumbura au Burundi, il est veuf, il 6 enfants entre 24 et 10 ans.
deux de ses enfants vont à l'école,son niveau d'étude est secondaire. il est chauffeur d'une camiotte, cette camionette est non propriete.il veut acheter les pieces de rechange pour son vehicule. sa vision et son ambition c'est d'elever ses enfants en leur payant le minerval, jusqu'à un niveau d'etude elevé.
texts.en:
Callixte K. is a 54 years old man, born in Bujumbura, Burundi. He is widowed, has six children between 24 and 10 years of age.
Two of his children are attending school and he has a secondary level education. He is a van driver and the vehicle is not of his property. He wants to buy spare parts for this vehicle. His vision and ambition is to raise his children and be able to pay their school fees to allow them to achieve a high level of education.

loans.use: Purchase of vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are house rent bills and school fees.

She has operated a food vending business for the past two years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. Mwanakombo faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to open a retail shop business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bags of beans, wheat flour, cooking fat, oil and rice. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation.

loans.use: To purchase bags of beans, wheat flour, cooking fat, oil and rice.

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira S.  lives in Osh city, in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 45 years old and has two children. Elmira graduated from the Textile University in Ukraine as a production engineer. She is known as a very communicative and responsive person.

To find a means of subsistence for her family and help her husband to cover the family’s expenses, Elmira started her business in selling women’s clothes and trousers, using her start-up capital of 40,000 KGS. Year in and year out, she managed to broaden her business by widening her assortment of goods.  She also paid for the education of her daughter in China
  
But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the Osh city, Elmira lost her business, which was robbed and looted. Her husband, who supported and helped her in all activities, was injured in a shootout during the clashes and died.  This tragedy became a hard blow for Elmira’s family and children.

However, Elmira isn't giving up.  She is ready to resume her lost business and continue to work. For this very reason, Elmira is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her business selling women's clothes. She plans to rent a selling point at the local market.  With the revenues she anticipates from the business, she plans to pay for education for her son. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas, leading to increased employment and meeting the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to broaden an assortment of goods

loans.name: Saber

texts.ar: صابر في عمر 47 سنة متزوج وله اربع اولاد يحب عائلته ويكن لها كل اهتمام يريد ان يؤمن لها حياة كريمة وجديدة من خلال تطوير نفسه وعمله يعمل في ميني ماركت له في عمله 8 سنوات دائم التطور والتجديد له تاريخ مشجع مع المجموعة حيث كان يلقى الدعم الكبير من العائلة وقد ساهم في تطوير عمله يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء قطع سيارات وقطع غيار زيت للسيارات بهدف فتح مصلحة جديدة تزيد له من مدخوله وتدعم عائلته مادية وتطور عمله فهو له زبائن كثر من محيطه وله معارف كثيرة في محيطه العملي
texts.en: Saber is 47 and married with 4 children. He works in a mini-market and has 8 years experience. He loves his family very much and they are his priority. He wishes to secure a comfortable life for them by developing himself and his business. He has an encouraging history with Al Majmoua, which contributed to the advancing of his business. He wants this loan to purchase car parts with the goal of opening a new section in his business, and thereby increasing his income. He has the full support of his family, and wants to provide for them financially. He has many local customers and clients.

loans.use: Purchase of spare car accessories, spare parts, and automotive oil

loans.name: Nurgul's Group

texts.en:
Nurgul T., 48, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Balykchi. Together with her husband, she is raising two daughters. The first daughter studies at the university and the second is at school. 

Nurgul works as a teacher of history at a school and her husband works in the company “Kyrgyz Altyn.”  In order to earn additional money to support the family budget, the family breeds livestock animals. They have been doing this since their marriage. With the money received from the loan, Nurgul wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future, she wants to expand her business activity and provide her children with a good education. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon earns a living through farming. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells in her community. As a single mother, Sharon works hard to provide food, clothes and education to her 10-year-old child. She does her best to be a father and a mother to her child. Sharon hopes for her business to be stable.

Sharon is in need of seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She requested a loan of 8,000 PHP. This loan will help Sharon immensely in her farming.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Francine

texts.en: Francine is 35 years old, she has five children who are between the ages of 2 and 14 years old. Three of her children are in primary school while the others are not yet in school. Francine’s husband is an accountant. Francine sells foodstuffs such as beans, rice, and sugar. She is requesting a loan in order to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of beans, rice and sugar

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar K. is 53 years old.  He is the father of two daughters and lives with his wife and youngest daughter in their own small wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His eldest daughter lives separately.

Ganbaatar used to operate a transportation business that utilized a microbus to carry people on one of the remote bus lines of the city. More recently, he bought a small car and started running a taxi service in the city. Ganbaatar's youngest daughter goes to the local secondary school. He is a very hard-working person and has gained much experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. Ganbaatar wants to purchase a notebook for his youngest daughter this year.

The loan he is asking for will be used to increasing his working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Maria Elisa

texts.en:
Maria Elisa S. is from the village of Linangkayan, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 33 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Elisa owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, detergents, seasoning, spices and toothpaste in the local community. Maria Elisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Maria Elisa joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maria Elisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and beverages. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and beverages

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar: علي في عمر 56 سنة يعمل في محل ميني ماركت لبيع المواد الغذائية له 10 سنوات في عمله متزوج وله 5 اولاد يريد ان يؤمن الحياة الكريمة لعائلته دائم التطور والتجدد يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء مواد جديد للمحل وتطوير العمل يسعى الى تطوير عمله وله زبائن كثر من محيطه وجيرانه
texts.en: Ali is 56 and works in a mini-market selling groceries and has 10 years' experience. He is married with 5 children and wants to secure a comfortable life for his family. He is constantly seeking to develop and rejuvenate his work. With this loan he wants to buy new stock for his shop and advance his business. He has many customers from his neighborhood as well as others from his local area.

loans.use: Purchase of goods and expansion of his shop

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 39 years old and has 5 children who are between the ages of 3 and 20 years old. Two of her children have completed high school, while others are still in school. Esther owns a shop in which she sells various goods such as sugar, salt and soap. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more soap, salt and sugar.

loans.use: To buy shop items such as sugar, salt and soap

loans.name: Ange

texts.en: Ange is 32 years old and she has 4 children who are between the ages of 1 and 11 years. She owns a shop in which she sells soap, sugar, salt and cooking oil. Ange runs the shop together with her husband. Ange is requesting a loan in order to purchase more sugar, soap and salt. With the profits, Ange plans to feed her family and buy other necessities needed at home.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To upgrade his banana plantation by buying manure and pesticides for the plantation

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita R. is from the village of Linangkayan, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 66 years old. Conchita is widowed and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Conchita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, snack foods and coconut wine in the local community. Conchita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Conchita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conchita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Conchita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Conchita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Siyafisa Group

texts.en:
Funukwenzani is 57 years old and married with 5 children, aged between 10 and 16 years. She runs a general store in Stanger, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. She is standing on the far right in the photo above. 

Funukwenzani has been in this business for 2 years. She also earns income from the government’s child support grant. She says that the main challenge to her business is that the customers do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Business and KIVA to buy breads, fruits and vegetables, and canned food. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her buy a couch for her family. In five years time she would like to see her business on top and have one more employee.

loans.use: To buy canned food, breads, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a 58-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling vegetables. She lives in the municipality of Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her vegetables vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,500. Lourdes is borrowing PHP 10,000 to purchase more vegetables to sell. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lourdes aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: Additional working capital for selling of vegetables

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and rent bills.

She has operated a cereals shop for the past five years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Josephine faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to construct her own permanent house in the future.

With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase sacks of cow peas, beans, wheat flour and rice. She decided to join Yehu after being introduced by a member of Yehu.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of cow peas, beans, wheat flour and rice

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 52 years old, married and supports her family by fish vending and buying and selling of firewood.  She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her two businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Erlinda is borrowing PHP 17,000 to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Erlinda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en:
Miguela is a 58-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a sari-sari (general) store and a vegetable vending business.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. Miguela joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Miguela has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to add more products to sell to her customers so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business. Miguela is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase more products

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther C. is from the village of Linangkayan, Naawan, Misamis Oriental.  She is 54 years old.  Esther is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Esther owns and operates a mini-restaurant.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from serving a variety of different meals to customers like adobo and afritada in the local community.  Esther has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Esther joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Esther has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI.  This previous loan was used to to purchase additional raw ingredients and working capital.  Esther is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant.  This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Esther from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks to sell in the restaurant.

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Armando started his business 22 years ago.  He invested in rice farming.  He tills his land himself and plants rice crops.  He sells his harvest to his community.  Armando is happy that his business is improving little by little.  He is the provider in his family that's why he works hard to sustain his family.

Armando is applying for a loan of 20,000 PHP which he will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for his 3 children's education.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Ms. Esterlita R. is from the Barangay of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental.  She is 59 years old and single.  To make a living, she is presently engaged in the dressmaking business.  She’s been engaged in this kind business for 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from this business activity. 

In 2011, Esterlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita as an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program and she is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP as her first loan, which will be used as additional capital for her dressmaking business.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of their family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments, possible product innovations, and business expansion.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business.

loans.name: Quintin

texts.en:
Quintin K. is from the village of Barucboc. He is 44 years old. Quintin is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Quintin owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Quintin has been engaged in his business for over 24 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Quintin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Quintin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Quintin is requesting a new loan of 28,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Quintin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Letty

texts.en:
Letty is a 57-year-old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  rice selling and buying and selling charcoal.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. Letty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Letty has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 to buy additional rice so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and for house improvements. Letty is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of rice

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 52-year-old married woman who supports her family as a wholesaler/retailer of charcoal. She lives in the municipality of Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard selling charcoal, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Gloria is borrowing PHP 25,000 to fund the operation of her business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gloria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.use: To fund the operations of her business

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores A. is from the village of Simanoc, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 61 years old. Dolores is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Dolores owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, candies & beverages in the local community. She also buys and sells electronic load for several networks like GLOBE & SMART. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dolores joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & beverages. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Dolores from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store and a fishing business. Her husband Larry, who is 37 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 8 and 10 years old. Evelyn  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Evelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her second loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of business. Evelyn  is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Meali

texts.en:
Meali is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She operates a retail shop business; her neighbours and also passersby are potential customers. Meali faces a major challenge of theft in her business. She hopes to establish a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000 she wants to purchase sacks of sugar, detergent, rice, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: To  purchase sacks of sugar, detergent, rice, beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Merilene

texts.en:
Merilene is a married woman who lives in Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business. Her husband Bonifacio, who is 58 years old, works as a vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 24 and 28 years old. Merilene joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Merilene has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 to use as additional capital so that she can continue to save up for house repairs. Merilene is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sot

texts.en: Sot Y. is from the province of Kompong Cham.  Since 1998, she has made a living by growing rice on her own farmland. She usually generates a profit of about $2.50 each day to help support her family. Sot Y.’s husband is a local farmer as well as a classical musician, who performs with two children in ceremonies around the community. The couple has three children. Sot Y. would like a loan to pay for repairs to her old house. She used to hire a few domestic workers to repair the house.

loans.use: To pay for repairs to her old house.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora V. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 65 years old. Leonora is widowed. To make a living, Leonora owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, detergent & bread in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Siyazenzela Group

texts.en:
Thembelihle is 39 years old and married with four children, between the ages of seven and 20. She runs a clothing business in Mtubatuba in Kwa Zulu Natal, South Africa. She is pictured on the far right.

She's been in this business for 4 years and sells mats, new clothes, skirts and shirts at her home.  She says that the main challenges to her business are customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy mat materials, new clothes, skirts, and shirts. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to school. In the future, she would like to own a shop in town.

In her comments she thanks WDB and Kiva.

loans.use: To buy mat materials, new clothes, skirts, and shirts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Upgrading his banana plantation by buying manure and pesticides for the plantation

loans.name: Auxilladora

texts.en:
Auxilladora lives in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She is widowed. She works hard to provide for her children. She grows rice and owns a sari-sari (variety) store. She earns money by selling her harvest to rice traders. She says that the store also helps in providing their daily needs. Auxilladora is planning to start a backyard piggery.

Auxilladora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Auxilladora has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Auxilladora is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs and invest in backyard piggery.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and invest in backyard piggery

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

She has operated a food stall business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbours. In addition she also has real estate houses which contribute another source of income. Mwanahamisi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand and construct other rental houses in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, cooking fat, oil, and rice. She decided to join Yehu after being introduced by a member of Yehu.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, cooking fat, oil, and rice

loans.name: Ma. Dahlia

texts.en:
Ma. Dahlia R. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Ma. Dahlia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Dahlia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. She also buys and sells green bananas. Ma. Dahlia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ma. Dahlia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Dahlia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ma. Dahlia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HHSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Kean

texts.en: Kean S. is a married woman who is good at cooking many kinds of meals for sale. Currently, she sells breakfast food to students in the local school. She can earn a profit of approximately $5 per day to support her family. Her husband works as a soldier, and he always contributes his monthly salary to Kean S.. In order to increase her revenue, Kean S. is asking for a loan to invest more capital in expanding her food-selling business. She has two single children, who still live under her roof.

loans.use: To expand her food-selling business.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza G., from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Orienta, is 31 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Liza owns and operates a specialized retail store selling green and yellow bananas in the local community. Engaged in her business for over eight years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her fourth loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional green bananas to sell. Liza plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional green bananas to sell

loans.name: Ruperto

texts.en:
Mr. Ruperto D., 37 years of age and single, is a resident of Digson, Bonifacio, Miss. Occ. To make a living, he works at ELIM INC. as Broiler Production Specialist, earning an average net income of not less than P5,000.00 a month. He is also engaged in a business entitled Buy and Sell NFA Rice and Distributor.

Ruperto joined PAGLAUM MPC in 2010 because he was very much interested in our products and services and the fact that we are one of the best cooperatives in Northern Mindanao. As a second-time borrower, he is entitled to avail the amount of P50,000.00 as additional capital for his Buy and Sell Business.

loans.use: Additional capital for NFA Rice Buy and Sell Business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a single woman living in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent. Florence has operated a cloth-selling business for the past year, selling from door to door to her neighbours. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business but hopes to establish a boutique shop from which to sell clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase 50 pairs of lessos (Kikois) to sell. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation.

loans.use: To purchase 50 pairs of lessos (Kikois) for sale.

loans.name: Bonifacio

texts.en: Bonifacio, 50 years old, lives in the town of Sto. Niño with his family. He is engaged in farming and primarily plants rice crops, selling his harvest to his community. Bonifacio wishes to succeed in his business and also hopes for the time when he will have his own money for capital. Right now, he is very thankful to be a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan of 17000 PHP to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. Bonifacio says his previous loans helped a a great deal in sustaining his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, additional seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Cora

texts.en:
Cora T., from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Oriental, is 41 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Cora owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including sardines and mackerel in the local community. She also buys and sells green bananas. Cora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Cora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her sixth loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional fish such as sardines and salmon to sell. Cora plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish such as sardines and salmon to sell

loans.name: Frederick Boima's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you this group of borrowers from the Eastern Polytechnic school in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. Staff of this institution have come to SMT for a loan of SLL 9,500,000 in order to improve  their standard of living. Some of them will use this loan to buy house building materials, some to buy pieces of furniture, others to pay school fees for their children, and so on.  At the end of each month, the institution’s bursar is directly responsible to deduct their repayment amount and pays SMT on their behalf.  This is the first loan that this institution has applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders.

Frederick Boima K. is the leader of this group. The 43 year-old Frederick was born in a village called Dawa, in eastern Sierra Leone. He is a teacher and has been in the teaching profession for 8 years. Frederick is married and has 5 children – 2 in primary school, 2 in secondary school and 1 in college. Frederick has requested this loan in order to pay college fees for his child and to invest the remainder in business.

loans.use: To pay college fees for his child and invest the remainder in business

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 46 years old. Delia is married and has 2 children, aged 21 and 14. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business raising crops.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Delia also grows pigs for fattening and sale.

Delia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Delia is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and pig feeds.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and pig feed

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy some essential materials for her business

loans.name: Nzioki

texts.en:
Nzioki is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and rent bills.

She has operated a cereals business for the past four years, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Nzioki faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to purchase a posho mill (grinding machine for maize) in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Upgrading his banana plantation by buying manure and pesticides for the plantation.

loans.name: Philister  Auma

texts.en:
For four years, Philister Auma has been running a salon and boutique, where she earns a monthly profit of KES.10,000. She is 44 years old, married and a mother of three children.

Philister Auma was introduced to KADET LTD by members of a group that is already registered in KADET. She is applying for her first loan from KADET.  She plans to use the loan to buy more stock of weaves and cosmetics for sale.

She will use the profit generated to pay school fees.  In the future, she plans to grow her business to be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy more weaves and cosmetics

loans.name: Bo

texts.en:
Bo V. is a 49-year-old farmer who lives in Phnom Penh City. Bo V. is married to Mr. Seng Sorl, age 48, who is a motorcycle-taxi driver in the busy market. This family usually earns an income about $5 each day to use for the family expenses. 

The daily profit in Bo V.’s family comes from her husband's business. Unfortunately, an existing motorbike often has broken down while providing the motorcycle-taxi service. Because of that, Bo V. has decided to seek a loan of $1200 from Kiva, which she will use to change the broken motorcycle for her husband. With the loan, she will be able to mend her house. 

This couple is blessed with three children, two of whom work in a variety of jobs for a profit while the other one is still young.

 Note: Bo V. and her young kid are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To change the broken motorcycle for her husband

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and house rent. 

She has operated a clothes business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby.  In addition, she also sells vegetables, which contributes to her other source of income. Rose faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a permanent house in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase ten bundles of clothes and sacks of vegetables for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase ten bundles of clothes and sacks of vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Mumuwa Community Bank-Mpigi Group

texts.en:
39-year-old N. Aisha operates a retail shop in Mirembe-Mpigi. The shop has been in existence for the past 8 years and mostly serves the rank and file residents in and around her area. She mostly deals in rice, soap, wheat, maize flour, etc. Aisha also does some part-time farming.

Aisha is happily married with five kids and she says with this loan she is going to purchase more general merchandise to resell. She belongs to Mumuwa community bank.

loans.use: the purchase of more general merchandise to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to repair his taxi or purchase a new one

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca A. is from the village of Gusa, Calatunan. She is 55 years old. Francisca is married and has ten children. To make a living, Francisca owns & operates a sari-sari store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from vending food items. Francisca has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Francisca joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisca is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to add to her working capital. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Francisca from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store

location.town: Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Edelina

texts.en:
Edelina F. is from the village of Poblacion. She is 52 years old. Edelina is already a widow. To make a living, Edelina owns & operates a restaurant. Edelina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Edelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edelina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to add to her working capital. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Edelina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her restaurant.

location.town: Poblacion, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a single woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a clothes selling business for the past six years, selling from door-to-door to her neighbours and passersby. Lucy faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation when moving from door-to-door. She hopes to establish a boutique in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Abla  Jacqueline

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Jacqueline  a 28 ans et est mère de 2  enfants.  Elle fait le commerce de pagnes et produits de beauté pour   participer  aux besoins  de ces enfants.  Elle a commencé son activité en 1989 et  s’approvisionne  au grand  marché  de Lomé.   Elle    habite quartier  Dzifa-kpota  où elle exerce son commerce.  Elle demande un prêt pour  acheter  de nouveaux lots de pagnes et produits de beauté.
texts.en:
Ms. Jacqueline is 28 years old and the mother of two children. She sells pagnes (colorful print fabrics) and beauty products to provide for her children. 

She started her business in 1989, and gets her stocks at the grand market of Lomé. 

She lives in the Dzifa-Kpota district, where she also conducts her activities. She is seeking a loan to replenish her stocks of pagnes and beauty products.

loans.use: To purchase pagnes and beauty products

loans.name: Ndyomugyenyi

texts.en:
Ndyomugyenyi L. is an individual client from Rukungiri. He is 30 years old and married with three children aged 8, 7, and 2 years. L. owns a car that he uses to transport people to their desired destinations. He has been in business for over five years and he is grateful that he is able to make an average profit of 620,000/=. This is in addition to the profits he gets from the sale of coffee. 

He works with his wife especially in the buying and selling of coffee. L. says that he is also a farmer and this he has done since he was very young since it is a family thing to be involved in agriculture. He needs a loan to be able to repair his car.

loans.use: His car maintainence and repair

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing a new motorcycle for his taxi business

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is a married woman with seven children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that  has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a groundnuts sales business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also sells firewood which is her other source of income. Eva faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. She hopes to establish a greengrocery shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of groundnuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of groundnuts for sale

loans.name: Yerimiya

texts.en: Yerimiya is a sixty-year-old married man with six children living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He rears animals and also distills alcohol for a living. In a good season he can distill five jerrycans of alcohol despite problems in transportation, and his dream is to distill at least ten jerrycans of alcohol and also diversify into onion growing. Yerimiya intends to use the loan to prepare land for growing onions.

loans.use: Preparation of land for growing onions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying onions for planting

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en: Godwin is a twenty-six-year-old married man with one child living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is charged with the responsibility of taking care of his family and his dream is to build a permanent house as a residence. For five years he has been growing tomatoes and per season he is able to harvest twenty crates of tomatoes. He has challenges with transportation, and his dream is to harvest at least two hundred crates. Godwin needs the loan to buy sprays for his tomatoes.

loans.use: Buying spraying chemicals for his tomatoes

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher is a twenty-eight-year-old married man with two children living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is into a number of businesses which include maize-growing, brick-laying, and goat selling. His major challenge is price fluctuation of maize and his desire is to have a store of maize. Christopher needs the loan to plant maize.

loans.use: Planting maize

loans.name: Janerose

texts.en: Janerose is a forty-seven-year-old hard-working married woman with eight children living in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is into motorcycle transport and farming which have enabled her to sustainably provide for the family. She has a challenge of the motorcycle rider not paying on time, and her dream is to have at least three motorcycles. Janerose intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a 25-year-old married man with two children. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is charged with the responsibility of looking after his family. His desire is to build a permanent house, as he currently lives in a semi-permanent house. 

For six years he has been involved in a butcher business, which has helped him to provide for the basic needs of his family. His business challenge is employees who do not remit their daily sales promptly. He plans to buy land and start raising animals. Richard needs this loan to buy land.

loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to plant onions

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn lives in the town of Sto. Niño with her family. She earns a living through farming. She plants and harvests rice crops and raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market. Evelyn strives hard to improve her business and her earnings.

Evelyn is in need of seeds, fertilizers and other supplies for her farm. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Ayawovi

texts.fr: Madame Ayawovi  est mère de 3 enfants et a 50 ans. Elle est née à  Aného et habite quartier Kégué.  Elle est revendeuse de charbons de bois  et céréales à la devanture de sa  maison.  Elle a  commencé en   2000 son activité  et  s’approvisionne à  Anié.  Elle sollicite un  prêt  pour  acheter  50 sacs de  charbons  de  bois.
texts.en: Mrs. Ayawovi is a mother of three children. She is 50 years old. She was born in Aného and lives in the Kégué district. She sells charcoal and cereals in front of her house. She launched this business in 2000 and stocks up in Anié. She is seeking a loan in order to purchase 50 bags of charcoal.

loans.use: Purchasing charcoal

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a 58-year-old married man with eight children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. Charles has been in the limestone business for 45 years, starting out by selling substandard limestone and now selling the fine one. His hardship is the difficulty of working in the rainy season. Charles' dream is to diversify into selling charcoal and firewood. Charles needs this loan to buy charcoal and firewood to resell.

loans.use: to buy charcoal and firewood to resell

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a single woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Sophia has operated a business selling clothes for the past seven years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Sophia faces a major challenge of clothing price fluctuations in the market. She hopes to open a boutique shop in the future. Sophia plans to use this KES 40,000 loan to purchase bundles of secondhand clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Momoh B.a's Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the KMDEC Moiwo St I & II in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. This school was founded in 1960 by the Kallon family in order to improve education in the district. This school is currently staffed with 71 teachers and has an enrollment of 1692 pupils.

This is the first time that teachers of the KMDEC primary school have benefited from a loan from SMT/Kiva lenders. They have requested a loan of SLL 13,100,000 to enable them to buy or invest in something that their meager salaries cannot let them do.

Momoh B.A. A. is the leader of this group of teachers. He was born in Vaahun village in eastern Sierra Leone and has been in the teaching profession for 35 years. Momoh is 51 years old and married to a businesswoman. They have 6 children – 2 in college and 4 adults. With his share of this loan, Momoh will pay college fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay his children's college fees

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to grow his business and purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel H. lives in Tolors village of Syunik region, famous for its severely harsh climate conditions. In the winter, it is extremely cold, and in the summer it is very hot. The land is not suitable for growing anything but potatoes. That is why most villagers, including Abel, keep livestock to insure an income for their families.

Abel lives with his wife, four young children, and his mother. The children are growing, so are their needs. Abel wants to insure his family is fed and his children are educated. It is vital for his family to increase their profit through purchasing additional sheep.

loans.use: buying sheep

loans.name: Muhindo

texts.en: Muhindo is a 38-year-old married man with six children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the milling and fabrication businesses for fifteen years. He started with a maize mill and now has several businesses. His primary business challenge is insufficient electricity, which causes damages. His vision for the future is grading and packing maize flour, as well as educating his children. Muhindo needs this loan to buy coffee and maize for resale.

loans.use: To buy coffee and maize

loans.name: Jinnilyn

texts.en:
Jinnilyn L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 36 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Jinnilyn owns a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Jinnilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. She hopes for an increased harvest through this loan.

loans.use: to purchase rice seed, fertilizer and other farming supplies

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick is a forty-year-old married man with four children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the bar business for six years. He started with four crates of beer and now has thirteen crates. His problem is bad debtors; his vision is to have a well-established bar accommodating 200 people, and to educate his children. Fredrick needs the loan to renovate his bar.

loans.use: Rennovation of his bar
